articles.headline: In Post-Roe America, Nikki Haley Seeks a New Path on Abortion for G.O.P.
articles.snippet: In crafting an anti-abortion message that doesn’t alienate moderate Republicans and swing voters, her approach has won both supporters and detractors.
articles.abstract: In crafting an anti-abortion message that doesn’t alienate moderate Republicans and swing voters, her approach has won both supporters and detractors.
articles.lead_paragraph: In May 2016, Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina walked down the aisle of the statehouse, beaming and shaking hands, after signing legislation that would largely outlaw abortion in the state after 20 weeks of pregnancy.

articles.headline: President Biden Keeps Hunter Close Despite the Political Peril
articles.snippet: The possibility of a federal indictment of Hunter Biden stunned the president. Yet the bond between him and his only surviving son is ironclad.
articles.abstract: The possibility of a federal indictment of Hunter Biden stunned the president. Yet the bond between him and his only surviving son is ironclad.
articles.lead_paragraph: Earlier this summer, President Biden was feeling hopeful.

articles.headline: Spain’s Top Soccer Official Resigns Over Unwanted World Cup Kiss
articles.snippet: Pressure had been building on Luis Rubiales, with prosecutors opening an investigation, his soccer federation calling for him to step down and FIFA suspending him.
articles.abstract: Pressure had been building on Luis Rubiales, with prosecutors opening an investigation, his soccer federation calling for him to step down and FIFA suspending him.
articles.lead_paragraph: The head of the Spanish soccer federation, Luis Rubiales, resigned on Sunday, weeks after kissing a member of Spain’s women’s team on the lips after the team won the World Cup last month, setting off a national scandal and drawing accusations of abusing his power and perpetuating sexism in the sport.
articles.byline: By Michael Wolgelenter and Rachel Chaundler

articles.headline: In Quake-Battered Mountains, Many Moroccans Must Fend for Themselves
articles.snippet: In a critical period for search-and-rescue teams, the Moroccan government has given few updates about its response and the scope of the destruction.
articles.abstract: In a critical period for search-and-rescue teams, the Moroccan government has given few updates about its response and the scope of the destruction.
articles.lead_paragraph: With debris and fallen rock blocking roads to Moroccan villages hit hardest by an earthquake, many residents began burying their dead and foraging for scarce supplies on Sunday as they waited for government aid.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee, Aida Alami and Jenny Gross

articles.headline: Biden Forges Deeper Ties With Vietnam as China’s Ambition Mounts
articles.snippet: Visiting Hanoi, the president cemented a new strategic partnership that puts the memories of the past behind them and focuses on mutual concerns over Beijing’s assertiveness in the region.
articles.abstract: Visiting Hanoi, the president cemented a new strategic partnership that puts the memories of the past behind them and focuses on mutual concerns over Beijing’s assertiveness in the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden cemented a new strategic relationship with Vietnam on Sunday, bringing two historical foes closer than they have ever been and putting the ghosts of the past behind them out of shared worry over China’s mounting ambitions in the region.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: China May Ban Clothes That Hurt People’s Feelings. People Are Outraged.
articles.snippet: A proposal evokes memories of 1980s China, when opening up to the world set off a debate over flared pants and men with long hair, what the party called “weird attire.”
articles.abstract: A proposal evokes memories of 1980s China, when opening up to the world set off a debate over flared pants and men with long hair, what the party called “weird attire.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, people in China could land themselves in trouble with the government for their fashion choices.

articles.headline: Theaters of War That Make Up the Fighting in Ukraine
articles.snippet: A “striking fist” in the North, and river crossings in the South. Along a jagged 1,000-mile front, the fighting is multifaceted — and relentless.
articles.abstract: A “striking fist” in the North, and river crossings in the South. Along a jagged 1,000-mile front, the fighting is multifaceted — and relentless.
articles.lead_paragraph: Along the southern reaches of the Dnipro River, Ukrainian forces are staging amphibious assaults on Russian positions across the river from around the city of Kherson, forcing Russia to deploy already-stretched units to prevent Ukraine from gaining a foothold on the eastern bank.

articles.headline: Microsoft, Google and Antitrust: Similar Legal Theories in a Different Era
articles.snippet: The government’s antitrust case against Google borrows heavily from the landmark lawsuit against Microsoft 25 years ago. But it lacks the same cultural impact.
articles.abstract: The government’s antitrust case against Google borrows heavily from the landmark lawsuit against Microsoft 25 years ago. But it lacks the same cultural impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department argues in a federal antitrust suit that Google is a dominant tech company that has abused its market power to bully industry partners, protect its monopoly and thwart competition.

articles.headline: As Smartphone Industry Sputters, the iPhone Expands Its Dominance
articles.snippet: Apple, which is set to release a new iPhone on Tuesday, has increased its share of smartphone sales by converting Android customers and adding teenagers.
articles.abstract: Apple, which is set to release a new iPhone on Tuesday, has increased its share of smartphone sales by converting Android customers and adding teenagers.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s a general rule about consumer electronics: The older a device becomes, the more competitors appear and prices fall. This was true for televisions, personal computers and portable music players.

articles.headline: Chinese Warnings on iPhones Tap Deep Strain of Security Concerns
articles.snippet: For years, officials in China have been told to shun foreign devices. Now reports of renewed curbs have unnerved Apple’s investors, heightening geopolitical tensions.
articles.abstract: For years, officials in China have been told to shun foreign devices. Now reports of renewed curbs have unnerved Apple’s investors, heightening geopolitical tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: China has discouraged the use of foreign-made electronic devices by government officials for a decade. It has told agencies and state-owned companies to replace American computer servers and other devices with domestic ones. And officials frequently show off to Americans their phones made by Huawei, China’s cellphone giant.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher, Chris Buckley and Tripp Mickle

articles.headline: Disney and Charter Reach Agreement, Ending Cable Standoff
articles.snippet: The impasse between the two companies had raised questions about the future of the cable bundle.
articles.abstract: The impasse between the two companies had raised questions about the future of the cable bundle.
articles.lead_paragraph: Disney and Charter said Monday that they had reached a deal to resolve their programming dispute, ending a skirmish that raised questions about the future of cable television.
